title_tesim: "Playing prepares the child for his future life."
title_ssim: "Playing prepares the child for his future life."
collection_tesim: Early Soviet Posters Collection
collection_ssim: Early Soviet Posters Collection
description_tesim: "Playing prepares the child for his future life." "Adults should find him a toy that would help him with that. This is how a child finds himself a toy without the help of an adult. Rummaging in the garbage pits, the child becomes infected with all sorts of diseases. On the left side of the poster: Harmful toys. Everyone takes them in their mouths and this way they spread the diseases. Having played and dirtied them, the child eats them and often falls ill. A child does not need small, rough, poorly painted toys; on the right: Useful toys. Playing with a ball makes the child agile, develops his body. The child runs for the hoop, jumps over the rope and exercises his arms and legs. Such toys give the child an interesting activity." (Игра подготовливает ребенка к будущей жизни. Взрослые должны позаботиться о такой игрушке, которая помогала бы ему в этой игре. Вот как отыскивает себе игрушку ребенок без помощи взрослых. Роясь в мусорных ямах, ребенок заражается всякими болезнями. Слева: Вредные игрушки. Их всякий берет в рот и таким образом они разносят заразу. Наигравшись и выпачкав их, ребенок их съедает и часто заболевает. Мелкие, грубые, плохо покрашенные игрушки не нужны ребенку. Справа: Полезные игрушки. Игра с мячом делает ребенка ловким, развивает его тело. Бегает ребенок за обручом, прыгает через скакалку и упражняет свои руки и ноги. Такие игрушки дают ребенку интересное занятие). Image of contrasting appropriate and inappropriate toys for children with captions

title_tesim: Gold and Jewel Pendant
title_ssim: Gold and Jewel Pendant
collection_tesim: Lord and Lady Palmer Collection
collection_ssim: Lord and Lady Palmer Collection
description_tesim: A pendant made of gold, unknown metal underneath as the base, turquoise, pearl, red spinel or ruby owned by Sharaf un-Nisa. This gold pendant is a pear shape. It is made of gold and is inlaid with turquoise, pearl, and either carnelian or ruby. The back is plain, and it is clear that the top is made of layers of metal overlaid to create dimensionality to the pendant. There is an open loop at the top of the pendant to allow it to be threaded.
description_ssim: A pendant made of gold, unknown metal underneath as the base, turquoise, pearl, red spinel or ruby owned by Sharaf un-Nisa. This gold pendant is a pear shape. It is made of gold and is inlaid with turquoise, pearl, and either carnelian or ruby. The back is plain, and it is clear that the top is made of layers of metal overlaid to create dimensionality to the pendant. There is an open loop at the top of the pendant to allow it to be threaded.
note_tesim: During the Georgian era, gold alloys in jewelry usually were 18 karats or more, so an alloy of copper and zinc first created by Christopher Pinchback that closely resembled gold allowed the general public to wear more jewelry without purchasing more expensive gold items. Iron and cut steel were also especially popular during this period. Due to the lack of standards of gold assaying, there was little way to verify the purity of gold in this pendant and another metal could easily be passed off as authentic. There also lacks any sort of mark or stamp by the maker, signifying its authenticity and who made it. The advent of the rolling mill, or a machine which passes through metal stock to create uniform thickness and structure, in the mid 18th century made the production of gold and silver jewelry more streamlined. As were most Georgian and Regency-era jewelry, this pendant has a closed back to "foil" or place a thin sheet of metal behind the gems to reflect more light. The gems appear to be cut in a mixture of ways, including cabochon and briolette cuts. Red spinel and ruby are two reddish types of gemstones commonly featured in Mughal jewelry.
note_ssim: During the Georgian era, gold alloys in jewelry usually were 18 karats or more, so an alloy of copper and zinc first created by Christopher Pinchback that closely resembled gold allowed the general public to wear more jewelry without purchasing more expensive gold items. Iron and cut steel were also especially popular during this period. Due to the lack of standards of gold assaying, there was little way to verify the purity of gold in this pendant and another metal could easily be passed off as authentic. There also lacks any sort of mark or stamp by the maker, signifying its authenticity and who made it. The advent of the rolling mill, or a machine which passes through metal stock to create uniform thickness and structure, in the mid 18th century made the production of gold and silver jewelry more streamlined. As were most Georgian and Regency-era jewelry, this pendant has a closed back to "foil" or place a thin sheet of metal behind the gems to reflect more light. The gems appear to be cut in a mixture of ways, including cabochon and briolette cuts. Red spinel and ruby are two reddish types of gemstones commonly featured in Mughal jewelry.

provenance_tesim: Bequeathed by Benjamin Franklin to his grandson William Temple Franklin. Bequeathed by William Temple Franklin to George Fox who in turn passed on possession to his children, Charles and Mary. Found at the Fox family estate at Champlost in a stable loft by Mrs. Holbrook around 1862 and given to her by Eliza Fox subsequently. Sold by her son George O. Holbrook to a committee of friends of the University of Pennsylvania Library in 1903 and gifted by them to the University the same year.

Bequeathed by William Temple Franklin to George Fox who in turn passed on possession to his children, Charles and Mary. Found at the Fox family estate at Champlost in a stable loft by Mrs. Holbrook around 1862 and given to her by Eliza Fox subsequently. Sold by her son George O. Holbrook to a committee of friends of the University of Pennsylvania Library in 1903 and gifted by them to the University the same year.

title_tesim: Interview with Lydia Messmer: oral history
title_ssim: Interview with Lydia Messmer: oral history
collection_tesim: Records, 1969-1991
Lydia Messmer interviews (University of Pennsylvania)
collection_ssim: Records, 1969-1991
Lydia Messmer interviews (University of Pennsylvania)
description_tesim: The interviewee discussed why he chose the University of Pennsylvania and his evaluation of the dental school of the University. He also recalled his promotion as a faculty member, his winning of tenure, and his experience during the World War II period.
description_ssim: The interviewee discussed why he chose the University of Pennsylvania and his evaluation of the dental school of the University. He also recalled his promotion as a faculty member, his winning of tenure, and his experience during the World War II period.
extent_tesim: 9 videotapes (6 U-matic tapes and 3 VHS): accompanying material in the manuscript section of the collection.
extent_ssim: 9 videotapes (6 U-matic tapes and 3 VHS): accompanying material in the manuscript section of the collection.
note_tesim: Produced by the Multimedia Educational Technology Services, University of Pennsylvania.

Lester W. Burket earned both his A.B.(1929) and his dental degree (1932) from the University of Pennsylvania. He also had a medical degree from Yale(1936). He served as Instructor in dental pathology at Yale, 1936-1937, and taught at the School of Dental Medicine of the University of Pennsylvania from 1937 to 1977. He served as dean of the Penn School of Dental Medicine from 1951 to 1972. He retired in 1977, won the honorary degree of Doctor of Science in 1978, and died in 1991. He was former president of the American Association of Dental Schools, Chairman of the Council on Dental Education, and Consultant to the U.S. Army, Navy, and Veteran Administration and the U.S. Public Health Service.
note_ssim: Produced by the Multimedia Educational Technology Services, University of Pennsylvania.

Lester W. Burket earned both his A.B.(1929) and his dental degree (1932) from the University of Pennsylvania. He also had a medical degree from Yale(1936). He served as Instructor in dental pathology at Yale, 1936-1937, and taught at the School of Dental Medicine of the University of Pennsylvania from 1937 to 1977. He served as dean of the Penn School of Dental Medicine from 1951 to 1972. He retired in 1977, won the honorary degree of Doctor of Science in 1978, and died in 1991. He was former president of the American Association of Dental Schools, Chairman of the Council on Dental Education, and Consultant to the U.S. Army, Navy, and Veteran Administration and the U.S. Public Health Service.

title_tesim: Rapport sur les poids et mesures : fait à la Société royale académique de Savoie dans sa séance du 22 décembre 1828
title_ssim: Rapport sur les poids et mesures : fait à la Société royale académique de Savoie dans sa séance du 22 décembre 1828
collection_tesim: Lawrence J. Schoenberg Collection (University of Pennsylvania)
collection_ssim: Lawrence J. Schoenberg Collection (University of Pennsylvania)
description_tesim: Excerpt from the register of the deliberations of the Société royale académique de Savoie, most of which is a report from a commission named to investigate the standardization of weights and measures. The report recommends the adoption of specific decimal liquid measures such as liters and the pegging of retained national measures, such as the pied for land area and the grenette de Chambéry for grain volume, to specific percentages of international decimal measures. Information at the end identifies the report as an excerpt, records that the report was unanimously adopted, and is signed by G. M. Raymond, secrétaire perpétuel de la Société (f. 12r).
description_ssim: Excerpt from the register of the deliberations of the Société royale académique de Savoie, most of which is a report from a commission named to investigate the standardization of weights and measures. The report recommends the adoption of specific decimal liquid measures such as liters and the pegging of retained national measures, such as the pied for land area and the grenette de Chambéry for grain volume, to specific percentages of international decimal measures. Information at the end identifies the report as an excerpt, records that the report was unanimously adopted, and is signed by G. M. Raymond, secrétaire perpétuel de la Société (f. 12r).
note_tesim: Ms. gathering.
Title from caption title (f. 1r).
Collation: Paper, 1¹⁴.

Layout: Written in 1 column of 29 lines on the right half of each page (left half used on one page for the rewriting of a canceled section); ruled in lead; left margin of text column marked both with lead and by folding.
Script: Written in cursive script.
Watermarks: BONTOUX, BEROUD.
Binding: Gathering sewn with silk ribbon, no covers.
Origin: Written in Chambéry in 1828 (f. 12r).
Lawrence J. Schoenberg & Barbara Brizdle Manuscript Initiative.
French.

Collation: Paper, 1¹⁴.

Layout: Written in 1 column of 29 lines on the right half of each page (left half used on one page for the rewriting of a canceled section); ruled in lead; left margin of text column marked both with lead and by folding.
Script: Written in cursive script.
Watermarks: BONTOUX, BEROUD.
Binding: Gathering sewn with silk ribbon, no covers.
Origin: Written in Chambéry in 1828 (f. 12r).
Lawrence J. Schoenberg & Barbara Brizdle Manuscript Initiative.
French.

note_tesim: Title supplied by cataloger (viewed on May 17, 2012).
Written in 9 lines per leaf.
97 leaves foliated [i], 1-94, [i-ii], left margin, alternating Sinhala and arabic numerals, recto and verso.
Dated 1881?
Mistakes crossed out; some corrections and additions in margins.
Ornately painted and varnished wood covers.
Dimensions of original manuscript: 44 x 6 cm.
In Pali (Sinhalese)

title_tesim: Affaire Dreyfus : croquis
title_ssim: Affaire Dreyfus : croquis
collection_tesim: Dreyfus Affair Collection (University of Pennsylvania)
Lorraine Beitler Collection of the Dreyfus Affair (University of Pennsylvania)
collection_ssim: Dreyfus Affair Collection (University of Pennsylvania)
Lorraine Beitler Collection of the Dreyfus Affair (University of Pennsylvania)
extent_tesim: [50] leaves of plates : all ill. ; 48 cm
extent_ssim: [50] leaves of plates : all ill. ; 48 cm
note_tesim: Title and statement of responsibility from spine.
Place and date of publication supplied from bookseller's description.
Comprises 76 lithograph illustrations mounted on 50 leaves of plates; each plate accompanied by printed guard sheet.

Table of contents: Planches séparés. Devant le panier à salade ; M. Joseph Reinach ; M. Bernard Lazare ; Famille du Cape. Dreyfus ; M. Rochefort, M. Déroulède M. Maurice Barrès, M. Quesnay du Beaurepaire ; M. Octave Mirbeau ; M. Jaurès ; M. Yves Guyot ; La Fronde ; M. de Rodays, M. J. Cornély ; M. Anatole France -- Procès Zola. Emile Zola ; M. Trarieux ; M. Clémenceau, Me. Demange témoin ; Expressions d'après le Comt. Esterhazy ; Avocats des deux parties adverses, M. Vaughan, Génaux. de Pellieux et Gonse ; Plaidoirie de Me. Labori ; Suite des gestes de Me. Labori ; Fin de la plaidoirie ; "Je sais bien que derrière M. le Procureur général, il y a le Ministre de la Guerre", Confidence -- Cour de cassation. A la porte de la galerie de Saint-Louis ; Entrée des Magistrats ; Toutes chambres réunies ; M. le Premier Président ; M. Bard, Me. Mornard ; Le coup d'œil de M. le Premier, M. Manau lisant son réquisitoire -- Procés de Rennes. Le Dossier ; Me. Demange ; Me. Labori ; Salle du Conseil de Guerre ; Le Génal. Mercier et M. Casimir-Périer à la barre ; Le Cape. Dreyfus parle ; Génal. Mercier et M. Cavaignac ; D'après les Généraux de Boisdeffre et Gonse ; Génal. Billot ; M. Bertulus ; 2e croquis d'après M. Bertulus ; D'après le Cape. Dreyfus ; Le Greffier M. Coupois, Comt. Lauth, La Dame blanche, Colel. D'Aboville ; Lieutt.-Colel. Picquart ; 2e croquis d'aprés le Lieutt.-Colel. Picquart ; Génal. Zurlinden, Cape. Freystœtter, Comt. Cuignet ; Déposition du Colel Cordier, M. Bertillon ; M. Gobert ; Comt. Forzinetti ; Le Cape. Dreyfus ; Comt. Carrière ; Aprés le Verdict ; Sortie du Lycée -- A Londres. 40 Upper Gloucester Place, Dorset Sq.

Dreyfus Collection copy consists of 1 bound volume containing 49 leaves of plates with guardsheets (all but "Sortie du Lycée") and 1 individual plate with guardsheet ("Sortie du Lycée"), housed separately.
Dreyfus Collection copy: guardsheets in volume numbered in ms. ("1"-"32", "34"-"50") in pencil.
Dreyfus Collection copy: illustration titled "Devant le panier à salade" dated and signed by the artist in black crayon: Paris le 5 Janvier 1895 à l'ecole militaire P. Rd [i.e. Paul Renouard].

Dreyfus Collection copy has ms. limitation and provenance note ("Tirage à 150 exemplaires ex: No. 31 à Monsieur Bischoffsheim, député. Paul Rneouard 46 rue de l'arbre-sec Paris") signed by the artist on blank leaf preceding first plate; ms. limitation note ("Tirage à 150 exemplaires ex: No. 65. P. Renouard 46 rue de l'arbre-sec Paris") signed by the artist on blank leaf following last plate.
Dreyfus Collection copy purchased for the Penn Libraries in 2018 from Jean-Baptiste de Proyart with the assistance of the Lorraine Beitler Dreyfus Fund.

Dreyfus Collection copy: volume bound by Devauchelle (with his stamp on verso of front free endpaper) in half gold-ruled brown morocco over marbled paper boards; 5 raised, gold-ruled bands on spine; gold-ruled spine panels; title ("Affaire DREYFUS Croques de Paul RENOUARD") stamped in gold on spine; date ("1894") stamped in gold at foot of spine; marbled endpapers. Housed in slip case.

title_tesim: The Asmonean. Volumes 1-3.
title_ssim: The Asmonean. Volumes 1-3.
note_tesim: "Knowledge is power."
Previously classed as a periodical in LC.
"A journal, devoted to the interests of the American Israelites", Dec. 6, 1850.
"Two are better than One, and a Threefold Cord is not quickly broken."
Publisher: Dinah Lyon, -1858.
Democratic. Supported Buchanan for President.
Chiefly in English with some Hebrew; v. 4, no. 10, published June 27, 1851 includes a German supplement; From Feb. 1856- each issue includes a German section called: Der Asmonean.
